awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: A Blueprint for Photocatalytic Water Splitting: Mapping Multidimensional Compositional Space to Simultaneously Optimize Thermodynamics and Kinetics
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Sunlight is a vast source of renewable energy but its intermittent nature means that its utilization requires a means of storing this energy. One attractive approach for solar energy storage is to harness the energy of sunlight to split water into hydrogen and oxygen i.e. solar generated fuels. The solar generated fuels can be combusted to release energy efficiently with water as the only by-product. As a result, this approach avoids the deleterious consequences of greenhouse emissions that accompany the combustion of conventional fossil fuels. The complex cascade of reactions required to harvest sunlight and split water into hydrogen and oxygen present a formidable scientific challenge. The project seeks to develop hybrid materials as the catalyst for water splitting, such that individual components are assembled and function synergistically. The project further works towards employing components that are highly tunable in terms of their energy levels, thereby providing a versatile platform that can be optimized for converting sunlight and water into fuel.  Employing a judicious mix of calculations from supercomputers and selective experiments accelerates the rational design of materials for efficient solar energy storage within chemical bonds. The project team mentors young scientists from underrepresented groups and engages K-12 students and teachers in activities that emphasize the opportunities made available by big data and solar energy.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The project explores the design of programmable heterostructured platforms for photocatalytic water splitting based on interfacing ternary vanadium oxide bronzes with semiconductor quantum dots. In the former compounds, metal cations are intercalated within a variety of open vanadium oxide frameworks, enabling a multitude of compositional possibilities and considerable energy level tuning. Moreover, the energy levels of quantum dots can also be tuned as a function of composition as well as size and the presence of cores. Photocatalytic water splitting requires not just the appropriate alignment of energy levels but also precise control of charge transfer dynamics. Interfacing two versatile and tunable components yields a rich multidimensional space for identification of effective photocatalytic architectures for water oxidation that yield holes at potentials only minimally positive to the water oxidation potential, thereby allowing for efficient conversion of sunlight to solar fuels. The multidimensional parameter space is mapped through a closely integrated and iterative combination of first-principles structure prediction, electronic structure calculations, diversified materials synthesis, detailed spectroscopy, high-throughput screening, and big data analytics. The activity involves development of an open-source platform for statistical analysis and mining of spectroscopic data. A summer research activity engages undergraduates from diverse backgrounds.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research project funded by the National Science Foundation’s DMREF (Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future) program involved the design, synthesis, and characterization of multi-component, or heterostructured, materials that store the energy of sunlight in chemical bonds through photocatalysis. In parallel with research efforts, our team strived to prepare research students, at the graduate and undergraduate levels, to join the next-generation materials workforce, and to broaden participation in scientific research through an internship program involving students from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM.

Intellectual merit:

The heterostructured photocatalyst materials that were the central focus of our research consist of vanadium oxides with intercalated metal cations (MxV2O5 compounds), interfaced with light-harvesting semiconductor nanoparticles or “quantum dots” (QDs). MxV2O5 compounds are semiconductors that, due to the properties of the intercalated metal cations M, have electronic states, or orbitals, within their band gap. The energetic distribution of these mid-gap states is tunable with the identity and amount of the intercalated cation M and the specific structure of the vanadium oxide framework. The other component of our heterostructures, QDs, have size- and composition-dependent band gaps and thus programmable properties as light harvesters and donors of excited-state charge carriers. Our team sought to take advantage of the tailorable electronic properties of MxV2O5 compounds and QDs by combining these materials components into heterostructures that promote fuel-forming chemical reactions, particularly the production of hydrogen (H2) under visible illumination. The mechanism of photocatalysis promoted by MxV2O5/QD heterostructures involved the absorption of visible light by QDs followed by the transfer of photogenerated holes (positive charge carriers) to the mid-gap electronic states of MxV2O5. Throughout the DMREF project, our team sought (1) to design, synthesize, and characterize nanoscale heterostructures with tunable energetic offsets at materials interfaces, and (2) to improve systematically the interfacial charge-transfer reactivity and photocatalytic performance of MxV2O5/QD heterostructures as platforms for solar photocatalysis. Toward these aims, we undertook an integrated, iterative approach involving first-principles theory; automated materials synthesis aided by data science, sequential learning, and high-throughput characterization; computational and spectroscopic studies of electronic structure and charge-transfer dynamics; and experimental characterization of photocatalysis. Through multiple design-predict-make-measure cycles, and progressing through five distinct generations of MxV2O5/QD materials formulations, we systematically developed heterostructures with optimal electronic structure and energetic offsets that promote ultrafast excited-state charge separation and efficient photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. Through these efforts, we uncovered new fundamental knowledge of structure-property-reactivity relationships involving the influence of materials composition, electronic structure, and interfacial properties on excited-state charge transfer photocatalytic performance. We expect that this knowledge will be broadly applicable towards the design and synthesis of materials and heterostructures for solar photocatalysis. To date, our research project has led to 20-plus peer-reviewed publications from Watson and Zhang, University at Buffalo PIs, acknowledging DMREF support, and upwards of 50 publications from across our full collaborative team.

Broader impacts:

Broadening participation: Our collaborative team ran a summer research internship program for undergraduate students from the University of Puerto Rico-Cayey (UPRC). A total of eleven URM undergraduate students, recruited from three workshops at UPRC, spent summers at the University at Buffalo and our collaborator’s institution, Texas A&M University. These students gained hands-on experience in advanced laboratory techniques pertaining to the design, synthesis, and characterization of materials heterostructures and the evaluation of their photocatalytic reactivity. They also learned core concepts underpinning the research project and key themes in materials chemistry and photochemistry, and they learned about the methodology of scientific research, particularly how to formulate hypotheses and to design experiments to test them. These students also developed communication skills through by preparing end-of-summer research presentations.

Student training and outcomes and helping to train the next-generation materials workforce: Numerous graduate- and undergraduate-student researchers, at the University at Buffalo and at our collaborators’ institutions, contributed to this DMREF project. These students designed and performed experiments, contributed intellectually to the development of the project and the planning of iterative, closed-loop design-predict-make-measure cycles, and gained hands-on and intellectual expertise in research methods spanning the range from materials synthesis, first-principles computations, data science, spectroscopy, and photochemistry. Ten PhD graduates from our research groups the University at Buffalo, and many others from our collaborators’ research groups, have gone on to research careers in academia and industry.
